C#: <source lang=csharp> if (object.ReferenceEquals(a  b)) {    // variables refer to the same instance  } </source>
Visual Basic .NET: <source lang=vbnet> If a Is b Then 'Can also be written as If Object.ReferenceEquals(a  b) Then    ' variables refer to the same instance  End If </source>

C#: <source lang=csharp> if (!object.ReferenceEquals(a  b)) {    // variables do not refer to the same instance  } </source>
Visual Basic .NET: <source lang=vbnet> If a IsNot b Then    ' variables do not refer to the same instance  End If </source>

C#: <source lang=csharp> if (a == b) {    // instances are equivalent  } </source>
Visual Basic .NET: <source lang=vbnet> If a = b Then    ' instances are equivalent  End If </source>
<source lang=vbnet> If a <> b Then    ' not equivalent  End If </source>

C#: <source lang=csharp> if (a is b) {    // types of a and b are compatible  } </source>
Visual Basic .NET: <source lang=vbnet> If TypeOf a Is b Then    ' types of a and b are compatible  End If </source>

C#: <source lang=csharp> if (!(a is b)) {    // types of a and b are not compatible  } </source>
Visual Basic .NET: <source lang=vbnet> If Not TypeOf a Is b Then    ' types of a and b are not compatible  End If </source>
